properties.name: Admiralty Bay
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Good Halibut Fishing here in the bay

properties.name: Chico Creek (mouth)
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter This is one of the best chum salmon runs around. From late September to early December, you can fish right off of the shore and catch as many as you can handle. Use a corky and yarn and try to floss them as they get concentrated at the mouth of the stream. To get there, take the Austin drive exit and turn east. Follow it all the way to the end (about 2 miles), and you\'ll see plenty of cars parked on the road. Dont forget to get a permission slip from the owner. He is a nice gentleman, and hands out over 200 each year.

properties.name: Gorst Creek
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Great King Salmon fishing from shore. I think now with the park there, you have to park at the gas station, or have someone drop you off maybe, and walk up the stairs and along the sidewalk on the overpass. You could probably also get permission from one of the local business along the water to park out of their way. There are several open parking lot spaces that they never use. I think this run starts in July. If you fish at low tide, I think you can walk out onto the mudflats to follow the tide line and floss these fish where the water is shallow. Bring some rubber boots.

properties.name: Horseshoe Lake
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter The lake has pretty good bass and trout fishing. For bass, without a boat, you can walk along a trail to the left side (when facing the water) of the county park. There are several "holes" along the short trail. Fishing near the downed tree is good, there is a little deep spot that is good, and then at the end of the trail there is a point that sticks out into the water. Fishing directly off the point, casting straight towards the center of the lake with a black and grey 4-6 inch rapalla has granted me over 20 bass, all around 1-2 pounds, in a couple of weekends.

properties.name: Iverson Spit
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter I\'ve heard there\'s some fantastic Sturgeon fishing up here at the public beach. I would like to verify this.

properties.name: Johns Creek (mouth)
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter A great chum salmon fishing spot. From late September to mid November, there are wall to wall fish here during the height of the run, 2nd, 3rd, and last week of October. There are quite a few people that fish here. Shoulder to shoulder at times, but its always fun.

properties.name: Long Lake
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Long lake is a great bass fishing lake. I hear they actually have some tournaments on the lake. While working on a house near the lake several years ago, I met an older gentleman who was out walking, said he lived on the lake since there were only 2 houses there 50 years ago. He had recently caught (probably in like 2004) a 16 pounder on the lake, had it mounted on his wall. That\'s a big bass. Anyway, take a boat around the edges of the lake and look for cover or structure. Maybe to the left side of the park if you are fishing from land.

properties.name: Long Lake Boat Launch and Fishing Area
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Right from the boat launch I have personally caught several 1-2 pound bass. casting directly in the middle of the launch, straight out, with a shallow water rapalla. Maybe a 3-5 foot under the surface, floating lure. Cast and reel, with lots of jigging and you\'ll be sure to get a few fish. Orange and Bass imitation colors worked best.

properties.name: Mid Channel Bank
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Great Halibut Fishing on the Northwest End

properties.name: Miller Bay Salmon Run
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Miller Bay, inside the little bay and in the larger part, are great in the summer for the king salmon run. There is also a blackmouth season for fly fishing only, catch and release, so I\'m told. Not to sure on this though. Anyway, the king run is pretty good.

properties.name: Mukilteo Halibut Run
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Almost along the ferry route; some spotty success fishing for Pacific Halibut.

properties.name: North of Gedney (Hat) Island
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter I\'ve heard rumors that there are some killer reefs around this island for lingcod and rockfish...

properties.name: Onamac Inlet
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter There\'s a man made reef in this inlet that is home to many rockfish, lingcod and salmon. Very rarely visited by seals, which is a big plus.

properties.name: Parking for Johns Creek
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter This area is marked public fishing. Good luck catching anything here though. You have to walk all the way around the golf course to the mouth of johns creek. About a mile I think. Probably a little less than that. Takes 10-15 minutes.

properties.name: Parking place for Johns Creek
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Parking for Johns Creek. Just pull off the highway into the large gravel area, and walk along the beach. Just as long a walk as around the golf course. Dont plan on parking here if you will need to come or go at high tide. The beach is impassable at high tide, and you\'ll have to walk way around to get back to your car. Tide doesn\'t have to be dead low or anything, just not right at high.

properties.name: Possession Bar
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Lingcod abound on both sides of this underwater bar. It gets lower the further out you go from the bay.

properties.name: Possession Point
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter This area consistantly proves itself as a reliable place to find fish. Probably due to the fact that it is a "fork in the road" to go up either side of Whidbey.

properties.name: Snohomish River (mouth)
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Great Salmon Fish

properties.name: Square Lake
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter This lake is full of beaver dams and huts. There are tons of bass and trout in this lake. If you have a boat (no gas motors), you can troll, and a resident on the lake (1 of only 2) said that when he trolls for trout, if he is going to fast, the bass will start hitting his line like crazy. I would fish with rubber worms, using a weedless setup if fishing from the park itself. My friend caught a 6 pound bass doing just that. If you walk down the trail, there are almost no lily pads, just be careful of a bee hive on one of the beaver huts. Crayfish imitation bates might do really well for bass, for trout, any spinners really, maybe night crawlers, but cast and reel, no sense in bobber fishing. :) This lake is not well known at all. Expect only a few people there when you go.

properties.name: Stillaguamish River (mouth)
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter I have heard rumors that, especially at the mouth, there are some monster Sturgeon in the stilly... not to mention it is a popular Coho/Pink salmon route. If you have any info on this, please post! :)

properties.name: Tulalip Bubble
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Located at the mouth of the Tulalip Bay where the Tulalip Chinook Hatchery feeds into, this place is usually hot for salmon when its open, which is earlier than the rest of area 8-2

properties.name: Wicks Lake
properties.description: Posted by Devonbaxter Please correct me if I am wrong, but I thought I read somewhere that wicks lake is all but barren. I dont remember what happened, but I\'m pretty sure that there are almost no fish in the lake, and that fishing here, although the lake looks good, is an uphill battle.
